bestBHT.bht: The call for leveling and smoothing the way, filling valleys and straightening paths, echoes the language of the Septuagint. It conveys the idea of overcoming obstacles, such as ravines and crookedness, that hinder progress. Removing these impediments allows both the lowly and depressed souls and the rough and resistant individuals to embrace Christ and find divine consolation. This clearing of hindrances paves the way for understanding the purpose of the Messiah's coming and His kingdom.

Henry Alford: are peculiar to Luke. They are nearly verbatim from the LXX in the Alexandrine copy.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: and smoothing, obvious figures, the sense of which is in the
first words of the proclamation, "Prepare ye the way of the
Marvin Vincent: Valley [φαραγξ] . Strictly, of a chasm or ravine in a mountain side."
On occasions of their progress, heralds were sent out to call on the people to clear and improve the old roads or to make new ones.
The exhortation 'to gather out the stones ' (Isaiah 61:10) is peculiarly appropriate.
Archibald T. Robertson: Valley (φαραγξ). It is a ravine or valley hedged in by precipices.
Shall be filled (πληρωθησετα). Oriental monarchs often did this very thing.
Crooked (σκολια). Common word, curved, opposite of ορθος or ευθυς, straight.
John Gill: Under which, such souls as were lowly and humble, and depressed with the sense of sin, should be raised and directed to believe in Christ, and be filled with divine consolation from him.

But what they say of this cloud literally, as preparing the way for the Israelites, is in a spiritual sense true, of the ministry of John whereby many of the children of Israel had the way prepared for them, for the reception of the Messiah.

And men of rough tempers, comparable to lions and bears, shall become quiet and peaceable, smooth and easy; and moreover, whatever difficulties were in the minds of men concerning the Messiah, the end of his coming, and the nature of his kingdom; and whatever impediments were in the way of embracing him when come, should now be removed at least from many persons.
John Wesley: Every valley shall be filled, … — That is, every hinderance shall be removed.

bhtAttempts.bht: The proclamation in Luke 3:5 calls for the leveling and smoothing of the way, using the imagery of filling every valley and straightening every crooked path. This language is nearly verbatim from the Septuagint, portraying a ravine or valley hedged in by precipices and crookedness as obstacles that need to be overcome. By gathering out the stones and filling these valleys, the way is prepared for the lowly and depressed souls, as well as the rough and resistant ones, to be raised and directed towards belief in Christ and the reception of divine consolation. The removal of hindrances clears the path for the coming of the Messiah, allowing many to embrace him and understand the purpose of his kingdom.

The proclamation in this passage emphasizes the need to level and smooth the way, filling every valley and straightening every crooked path. The language used, borrowed from the Septuagint, illustrates obstacles such as ravines and crookedness that hinder progress. By removing these impediments, the way is prepared for both the lowly and depressed souls and the rough and resistant individuals to embrace Christ and find divine consolation. This clearing of obstacles allows many to understand the purpose of the Messiah's coming and His kingdom.

The call for leveling and smoothing the way, filling valleys and straightening paths, echoes the language of the Septuagint. It conveys the idea of overcoming obstacles, such as ravines and crookedness, that hinder progress. Removing these impediments allows both the lowly and depressed souls and the rough and resistant individuals to embrace Christ and find divine consolation. This clearing of hindrances paves the way for understanding the purpose of the Messiah's coming and His kingdom.

The proclamation in Luke 3:5 emphasizes the need to level and smooth the way, filling every valley and straightening every crooked path. This language, nearly verbatim from the Septuagint, highlights the obstacles of ravines and crookedness that hinder progress. By removing these impediments, the lowly and depressed souls, as well as the rough and resistant individuals, are directed towards belief in Christ and filled with divine consolation. This clearing of hindrances prepares people to receive the Messiah, overcoming difficulties and removing obstacles to embrace His kingdom.

The proclamation in this verse calls for the leveling and smoothing of the way, filling every valley and straightening every crooked path. This language, borrowed from the Septuagint, uses vivid imagery to portray obstacles such as ravines and crookedness that hinder progress. By removing these impediments, the path is prepared for both the lowly and depressed souls and the rough and resistant individuals to embrace Christ and find divine consolation. This clearing of hindrances allows many to understand the purpose of the Messiah's coming and His kingdom.
